meanings.definition: A system of ideas and ideals, especially one that forms the basis of economic or political theory and policy.
meanings.sent1: The company's success was built on strong idealogies about innovation and teamwork.
meanings.sent2: Many political debates stem from conflicting idealogies about government intervention.
meanings.sent3: The idealogies of the rival soccer teams clashed on the field, leading to a heated match.
meanings.sent4: In the world of business, adaptability is often more valuable than sticking rigidly to outdated idealogies.
meanings.sent5: The idealogies of equality and justice are fundamental to a fair society.

meanings.definition: The study of ideas and their origin and nature.
meanings.sent1: Philosophers delve into the realm of idealogies to understand human thought processes.
meanings.sent2: Studying the idealogies of ancient civilizations can provide insights into their cultural development.
meanings.sent3: The professor's lecture on idealogies was so engaging that the students didn't notice the time passing.
meanings.sent4: Exploring the idealogies of different cultures opens up new perspectives on the world.
meanings.sent5: Understanding the idealogies behind scientific discoveries can shed light on the progress of knowledge.

meanings.definition: A set of beliefs or principles, especially one on which a political system, party, or organization is based.
meanings.sent1: The idealogies of the political party resonated with the voters, leading to a landslide victory.
meanings.sent2: The idealogies of the organization were clear from its mission statement and actions.
meanings.sent3: The idealogies of honesty and transparency were crucial for building trust within the community.
meanings.sent4: Sometimes, compromise is necessary when different idealogies clash in a negotiation.
meanings.sent5: The idealogies of freedom and democracy are cherished values in many societies.
